results.title: Magic lantern three-panel slipping slide (Flower Bloom)
results.brief_description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a flower bud blooming. Two adjustable sliding pieces of glass - slide left and right to show the flower blooming. Set against a black background. Made by W.F. Archer, Liverpool, 43 Lord St and 63 South Castle St. ‘49’ and ‘R’ written in pencil on wooden frame.
results.description: Magic lantern set effects slide with wooden frame. The coloured slide shows a flower bud blooming. results.title: The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit glass slides (Reptiles)
results.credit_line: ACMI Collection. Donated by William Kerr on behalf of Edwin Schefferle.
results.brief_description: There are three parts to the Reptiles slides, each slide has 4 images. These small slides have red sealing tape around the edges. These slides form part of The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit with removable chimney and internal wooden block. The lantern is housed in original box with metal handle, and internal red and blue graphic for: The Empire Magic Lantern Outfit. 20 glass slides in custom box, length of textile to keep box shut, 2 small empty boxes which act to store slides in a snug manner.

results.title: The Illustrated Auschwitz
results.creator_credit: Lucia Salinas Briones, Jackie Farkas and AFTRS
results.brief_description: Jackie Farkas uses the extraordinary and harrowing oral testimony of an elderly Hungarian woman as the basis for a poetic and abstract investigation into how cinema can ‘illustrate’ such profoundly horrendous experiences. The use of found footage, elusive images of beauty and horror and sequences from ‘The Wizard of Oz’ to elucidate the narrator’s memories creates an extraordinary representation of the holocaust experience, of survival, of home and memory, and of how we can comprehend the incomprehensible.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Lucia Salinas Briones, Jackie Farkas and AFTRS

results.title: Time-lapse footage of decomposing rat
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour, silent
results.brief_description: Remarkable time-lapse sequence depicting the natural decomposition of a dead rat. Produced by Oxford Scientific Films, this footage is as elegant as it is grotesque.

results.title: AstroTurf
results.creator_credit: Magnetic Monster Video, Australian Film Commission, Rod Bishop and Ian Haig
results.material_description: Single channel moving image, colour and audio
results.brief_description: ‘AstroTurf’ is a 3-D animation that tours through periods of time that mark different technologies, from the prehistoric to beyond the 21st century. As the technology advances, human evolution is virtually at a standstill, always at odds with the technology that is demonstrated to be fallible. Ian Haig uses bold graphic style drawing on influences such as; 1950s television, sci-fi imagery, computer games, cartoons and comic books. ‘AstroTurf’ becomes a platform to celebrate computer imaging and the alternate aesthetics that the medium allows for.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Magnetic Monster Video, Australian Film Commission, Rod Bishop and Ian Haig
